story: The Cartvale, in Busby, is hoping to make a name for itself for having one of the best beer gardens in the area once work is complete.The makeover will get underway from July , with the venue scheduled to reopen in late August, creating  new jobs.:Glasgow restaurant giving away dining prizes to celebrate th birthdayFull redecoration of the outside of the building will accentuate its character on Main Street.The garden will also receive a makeover and become a focal point. New decking and planting, seating for  and festoon lighting will enhance its setting next to White Cart Water.The inside of the pub will be given a stylish look, including new folding windows and a balustrade to provide views over the river and woodlands.A kitchen will be put in to enable new licensee Andy Crossan, from the south of Glasgow, to introduce new food to the pub, all with a Scottish slant.How the pub will look upon completionAndy said he wants The Cartvale to be ldquoa hub of the community and welcoming to all.He will open it up to local groups and clubs in need of meeting space and host a range of activities from quiz and board game evenings to music nights featuring bands from Glasgow and the West of Scotland.Andy is also investing in Sky TV so local residents can enjoy major sporting events.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesHe said: ldquoIrsquove worked in hospitality all my le and have always wanted a pub of my own.ldquoItrsquos fantastic to work in a positive environment where you see people having a good time. When I saw The Cartvale was available, I knew it was the one. Itrsquos in a great area I know well and has loads of potential. The plans are really exciting and the inside will be completely transformed when wersquore finished. I canrsquot wait to open the doors.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Tory leadership contenders are playing a game of liar s poker with public money
story: Im not saying that McDonnell is wrong. Jeremy Hunt and Boris Johnson, have been playing a game of liars poker with public money. Boris began by promising to cut taxes on the well off and also lt lower earners out of tax. Hunt replied by lting the threshold for National Insurance to pound,, cutting corporation tax to .% and effectively scrapping business rates for the vast majority of shops.And they were just getting started.:Letters: English nationalism demeans our politicsBy this stage, the contenders had become like poor souls in Las Vegas, at am on the third day, trying to make up their losses by going all in. Both made uncosted pledges on social care. An addled Jeremy Hunt said he would cut student debt and write off tuition fees for young entrepreneurs.The Barnett Formula, you ask  Boris Johnson may have railed against the Scottish spending calculus as ldquounfair, and ldquoinequitable ndash a tax on being English. But both he and Jeremy Hunt now praise the much-maligned formula as the essential glue of the Union, and have promised never to touch it. Indeed both candidates threw in poundbn for post-Brexit agriculture and fisheries.By now, the adults in the Tory poker room were beginning to fret. Spoilsport Chancellor Philip Hammond warned that theyd spent his ldquopoundbn fiscal headroom many times over. The Institute for Fiscal Studies went further and accused them of ldquomisleading votes by making spending pledges that could never be met, while cutting taxes for just about everyone. The IFS Director, Paul Johnson, pointed out that the poundbn was available for one year only.And Brexit  Well, Jeremy Hunts response to the Chancellors strictures was to toss in another poundbn to compensate industries hit by Brexit tarfs The IFS believe the cost of Brexit will be vastly greater than that. Yesterday, Philip Hammond said that a No Deal Brexit would cost poundbn. But this is now fantasy land and no one is really listening any more."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt talk at hustings in Belfast","description": "Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt talk at hustings in Belfast","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs tBuczLK-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests tBuczLK.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Now, you might just regard this all as pork-barrel politics as usual. Dont politicians always over-promise, throw money at the voters, spend astheres no tomorrow  Well, no actually they donrsquot ndash especially not Conservatives. You dont have to go back to the fiscally dry-as-dust Thatcher era to hear the mantra: ldquoonly spend what we can afford. The former Labour Chancellor, Gordon Brown, worshipped a god called ldquoprudence in the s, believing that Labour had lost successive elections because it couldnt be trusted with the purse strings of government.In  the Tories formed a government with the Liberal Democrats, which pledged to restore the nations finances by the most radical cost-cutting. It was called ldquoausterity". George Osbornes programme was compared to the ldquoGeddes Axe ndash the eye-watering spending cuts imposed by the coalition Chancellor, Sir Eric Geddes, in .:Neil Mackay: We need to start talking about the abolition of the monarchyIts worth reminding Jo Swinson, as she bids to be the next LibDem leader, that the Liberal Democrats endorsed Osbornes austerity. Indeed, Vince Cable, still says that austerity was ldquonecessary".No one  seems to be saying that. There has been a seismic sht in the politics of public finance as politicians have suddenly abandoned the old language of fiscal rectitude. And not just in Britain. President Macron of France has had to reverse his public finance reforms. Donald Trump, despite all his rhetoric, has just put forward a record . trillion budget.What seems to have happened is that politicians of left and right, but most strikingly of the right, have become influenced by the rise of the populists. Populism is often wrongly regarded as a traditional conservative ideology boosted by anti-immigration nativism. This is a mistake. Asand YouGovs six-month study of the phenomenon pointed out, populists are much more left than conventional right, and generally seek to reduce inequality.ldquoThis is not something we expected to see, said Kirk Hawkins of . ldquoPopulism, in the end, is attractive because it takes seriously the grievances of people who feel abandoned and unfairly treated. In the crucible of Brexit, the traditional party of the right has realised that it must do something to address these grievances, or cease to exist as a political force.Im not suggesting that populists are the New Left. Only a fool would believe the promises being made on public spending. Donald Trumps spending splurge has largely been on defence and building a border wall. But the change in the ideological agenda is too striking to ignore.Jeremy Corbyns  Labour Manesto emerges, in retrospect, as relatively modest in its spending proposals. The SNP under Nicola Sturgeon is also beginning to look a little, er, conservative in its approach to public finances.As the former SNP MP George Kerevan pointed out, the SNPs Sustainable Growth Commission report, with its plans to hold spending to % below GDP, has many similarities with the austerity programme of George Osborne after . At the very least, the SGC represents a covenant with the Scottish electorate that an independent Scottish Government would only spend within its means and would not indulge in radical deficit financing.Tell that to the Tories! Theyve discovered the magic money tree. They seem to be adopting the left wing economics of Modern Monetary Theory, which says that public spending deficits dont matter because governments can always print money.Of course, this is all in the context of Brexit. We are in an age of febrile politics. There will be a reckoning. When its over, and the tide goes out, well soon see, as Warren Buffet likes to put it, whos been bathing without their costume on.

title: Rosemary Goring  Why age isn   t a barrier to power in our youth-driven society
story: You canrsquot help wonderingthe rumours about Mr Corbynrsquos declining memory, attention span, strength and general fitness come from real evidence of reduced capabilities, orthey are a fiendishly contagious conspiracy, cooked up to topple him before he has a chance to become the next Prime Minister. Scuttlebutt insists that the -year-old is nothing but a puppet, leaning on colleagues for support, mouthing their ideas, and too decrepit to do much more than clutch the lectern and issue an occasional rallying call to his troops.With most unfrail alacrity, Mr Corbyn has refuted all these suggestions ndash apparently made by senior civil servants ndash and is asking for an independent inquiry into whoever is spreading such lies. He is right to insist on this, but sadly the damage is already done. Now every blink and tremor, every hesitation and stumble, will be cause for analysis and concern.No-one beyond the Labour leaderrsquos closest family and associates can know how much,any, truth this gossip holds. Wersquove been told about eye problems, but are they an indication of more serious underlying health problems  Or is it simply that the burdens of office are exhausting him, making him appear older than his years  Impossible to tell. With a man whose demeanour has always been more energy-saving bulb than dynamo, it is dficult to detect any appreciable dimming of wattage.As questions were being asked about his ability to run the party, let alone turn the key in the door of Number , I found myself thinking of Mr Corbyn when watching democratic hopefuls for the next US presidential nomination. Bernie Saunders, who will be  in September, is impressively impassioned, but he cannot surely be anybodyrsquos idea of the perfect candidate, given the demands that would be made of him in arguably the most high-profile and pressured job in the world. Joe Biden, too, at  is scarcely a spring chicken. Like Mr Saunders, he was born while the Second World War was getting into gear. As for the American president, even his worst enemies have to concede that at  he still seems to be possessed of enough energy to make international deals and travel the globe, with never a sign of flagging.This might all sound unpleasantly ageist. Yet with a few notable exceptions, most mortals begin to slow down intellectually as well as physically as they reach their biblical span of three score years and . This is not to say that there are not many fruitful, useful and enjoyable years ahead, but it is to suggest that the gruelling schedules expected of modern politicians, be they first ministers or presidents, senators or MPs, is no longer an arena in which those past their prime will easily flourish. A century ago, there would have been little or no public outcry over an elderly or enfeebled prime minister or party leadercolleagues could keep the government on track. In this, Britain had the benefit of centuries of precedent with royalty. From before the Stuarts to George III, kings and queens, with a little help from friends at court, continued to pass edicts and legislation, sign death warrants and go to war, while, whether through ill health, insanity or senility, they were completely unfit for office.Read more: Labour demands probe into civil serviceWith the onward march of democracy, however, has come greater visibility, transparency and accountability. Technology might have transformed our domestic workload, but for those in the political front line, the digital revolution has turned night into day. Dedication and accessibility   is the least voters now expect. No wonder so many images of MPs shows them in running gear, pounding the pavements and turning strawberry pink. This is not just a metaphor but a practical necessitythey are to survive the punishing regime their role demands.Despite much talk about our fast-ageing population, there has never been a period that is so youth-driven, or when the old have been so easily and cruelly dismissed as irrelevant or past-it because they have one foot still in a pre-tech world. The gulf between those born while ration books were circulating, and those whorsquod mastered an iPhone before their milk teeth were cut, is eye-wateringly wide. What does someone of pensionable age understand of the Snapchat generation  Other than the most basic human needs, such as security, work, and dignity, which transcend any barriers of time and class, colour and creed, what can an elderly politician offer a youthful electorate Well, perhaps more than yoursquod think. Clearly, what wersquore witnessing with the ongoing popularity of those like Mr Saunders and Donald Trump, is the triumph of longevity and experience over vigour. Their retro appeal is in part thanks to a letimersquos accumulation of high-powered connections and skills. Why be surprised that some dream even now of Ken Clarke taking over the Tory Party to bring it to its senses, despite him being almost as ancient as the Fortingall yew  Or that others rejoice at the distant prospect of Ann Widdecombe resurrecting her political career and ing as a Brexit Party MP.Experience, and the informed perspective it allows, is by far the greatest advantage of seniority. Is this what the young see when they look at people like Mr Corbyn, who lavishes more care on his allotment than on clear-cut policy yet commands widespread respect and even affection or why the venerable-looking Mr Saunders made such an impression with his brand of democractic socialism that he threatened to make Hillary Clinton toast It would seem so. Evidence suggests, indeed, that despite living in a world designed for youth, where to be in any way incapacitated or slow is to be invisible and ignored, we are nevertheless hard-wired as humans to defer to age. Rightly or wrongly, our instincts tell us that with wrinkles or bald pate, dentures or dodgy knees, comes hard-won wisdom. You might even argue that, far from being a handicap to reaching power, advanced age is actually an asset.

title: theresa-may-successor-dont-trust-nicola-sturgeon
story: In a blunt message to Jeremy Hunt and Boris Johnson, the Prime Minister said the SNPcould not be relied upon to act in ldquogood faith.Warning "we do not have good will on all sides", she said the next occupant of Number  must actively strengthen the Union or it would be "too late".She said: ldquoOver the last three years I have learned that while other parties can be relied on to work with the UK Government in good faith to make devolution a success, an SNP Scottish Government will only ever seek to further the agenda of separation.ldquoThat, I am afraid, is simply a fact of political le in the UK at the moment."That fact puts an additional responsibility on the UK Government. If we do not do all we can to realise the full benefits of the Union ndash no one  will."If we do not use every policy lever within our reach to strengthen that Union ndash no one  will."Andwe do not make realising the full benefits of being a United Kingdom of four proud nations and one united people our priority now, then in the future it may be too late.""@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Theresa May: My successor in Number  will make protecting union top priority","description": "Theresa May: My successor in Number  will make protecting union top priority","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs rCGAFVF-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests rCGAFVF.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": In her last official speech north of the border before her successor is named on July , Mrs May warned the next Prime Minister not to take the Union for granted, but actively promote and protect it from Nationalists working to bring about its end.She agreed with former Labour PM Gordon Brown that the UK was under threat.Describing Brexit as ldquoa profound constitutional change putting political and administrative strains on the Union, she said: ldquoWhen Gordon Brown recently said that he fears the Union is lsquomore imperilled now than it has ever beenrsquo he voiced the fears of many.ldquoI care passionately about our Union. I certainly do not underestimate the scale of the challenge it faces. But I am optimistic about its future.Mrs May was speaking to party activists in Stirling about strengthening the Union after  years of devolution, announcing a review of how UK Government departments could do so led by former Scotland Office minister Lord Andrew Dunlop.She said: ldquoToday, the only threat to devolution comes from those parties who want to end it by breaking up the United Kingdom.ldquoFor those of us who believe in the Union, devolution is the accepted and permanent constitutional expression of the unique multinational character of our Union.ldquoIt was ironic that the UK Governmentrsquos sincere efforts to ensure that Brexit had no unintended consequences for the UKrsquos internal market was dismissed as a lsquopower-grabrsquo by the SNP.ldquoA UK Government which had enthusiastically launched and implemented the Smith and Silk Commissions ndash transferring sweeping powers over tax and welfare - stood accused of using Brexit as the cloak behind which to claw-back powers over food labelling and fertiliser regulations. On one level the allegation is simply absurd.ldquoOn another, it highlights a challenge which faces the UK Government as it seeks to act in the best interests of the whole UK. Whereas the UK Government is invested in the success of devolution, it would suit the political aspirations of the present Scottish Government for devolution to fail, or to be seen to fail.She repeatedly cited the pledge by Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon that the  independence referendum would be a once in a generation or once in a letime decision.She said: ldquoIf a majority had supported independence, the UK Government would have accepted that result ndash no question. But the people of Scotland did not vote for independence.ldquoA clear and decisive majority of ten percentage points gave the Union their backing and their decision should be respected.ldquoSo when Nicola Sturgeon requested of the UK Government in  the power to legislate for a second independence referendum, just three years after that historic vote, I had no hesitation in firmly saying lsquonorsquo. In the future, it will be for others to decide based on the prevailing circumstances how to respond to separatism. But the principle is clear ndash the Union can and will only prosperit enjoys the support of its people.The speech was delivered on the eve of Mr Johnson and Mr Hunt appearing at the sole Scottish hustings in the Tory leadership contest in Perth tomorrow.Mr Johnson has promised to deliver Brexit by Hallowersquoen ldquodo or die, evenit means a no-deal that could boost support for the SNP and independence.Mr Hunt has said he believes in the Union ldquowith every fibre of my being, but has also set a no-deal deadline of September , saying he would be ready to take the UK out of Europe on WTO termsthere was no realistic chance by then of a renegotiated deal.Ahead of Mrs May speech, Mr Sturgeon predicted the Prime Ministerrsquos ultimate legacy would be Scottish independence.

title: radical-solution-needed-help-rural-schools-facing-teacher-shortages
story: The Strategic Board for Teacher Educationhas not published any definitive course of action, but the suggestion is trainee teachers could be sent to rural areas to help fill vacancies as a matter of course.As research has already shown, geography is a signicant challenge in recruiting teachers, particularly to rural areas, because most are trained in central Scotland and will not consider posts where.:Union leader Seamus Searson, who sits on the board, said these postings could be for up to two years and would be beneficial because of the wider responsibilities of working in a smaller school.However, trainees in their probationary year can already benefit from an additional payment of up to pound,they sign up to be posted anywhere in Scotland, but the scheme has not proved as successful as was hoped.Aberdeenshire Council reported in February that the number of probationers agreeing to work anywhere was lower than in previous years, suggesting any form of future coercion would be problematic.The council also has concerns about the impact on quality of plugging gaps with trainees. ldquoAlthough probationers are a welcome resource, particularlythose from outwith the north-east can be encouraged to stay, it should be noted that relying on probationers does result in a relatively inexperienced staff mix, which can cause concerns among parents, the same report said.:What is clear from the SBTE paper is just how much of an impact the staff shortages are having on schools.Longhaven School in Peterhead, Aberdeenshire, was mothballed in  after adverts failed to attract staff and the five remaining pupils had to be placed where.Argyll and Bute mothballed Minard Primary in Inveraray in October last year after being unable to recruit staff and the remaining three pupils were moved where.The report also found an increasing challenge recruiting and retaining senior staff in rural settings, with some authorities, including Dumfries and Galloway, recruiting headteachers to run up to three schools at once.And one potential solution - that of greater use of digital resources - has been problematic because rural schools also struggle with poor internet connection.

title: navy-marks-50-years-round-clock-nuclear-submarine-patrols
story: For every hour of every day since  the Royal Navy has had a submarine armed with nuclear missiles lurking somewhere under the worldrsquos oceans.This operation ndash the longest, most complex and surely most controversial in British military history ndash is called the Continuous At Sea Deterrent or CASD.Today it marks its half century with a military parade at its Scottish home, Faslane near Helensburgh, in front of Princess Anne and hundreds of visitors.The Ministry of Defence said the events would be a ldquorecognition of the huge national endeavour entailed in keeping submarines at sea.:What next for Britainrsquos undersea bombers Ballistic missiles, first Polaris and then Trident, have ided opinion like nothing  in defence strategy for every one of those  years of CASD, and, indeed, years before.These, after all, are weapons designed during the Cold War to obliterate Soviet and eastern bloc cities. They could kill millions. That is why their opponents do not like them. And it also is why their supporters say they serve as a deterrent.Yet, writing in todayrsquos Herald, St Andrews University expert Phillips OrsquoBrien stresses these weapon systems, however dangerous, however complex, have always been more ldquopolitical than practical.And Mr OrsquoBrien reckons that political role could be more important than ever. As Britain crashes out of the European Union, in a drawn-out squabble with nations that were once its closest military allies and trading partners, it will need a symbol of military virility.Few, however, quibble over the personal contributions of submariners, men who spend weeks away from their homes and families, sacricing privacy on cramped ldquoboats. Most never even know where they are when at sea. The danger of the work was underlined this week when a fire was reported to have killed sailors on a secret submersible in Russia.:What next for Britainrsquos undersea bombers Inspired by the warplanes of another age, the navy tends to think of the big ballistic missile subs as ldquobombers and of the nuclear-powered but not nuclear-armed hunter-killers as ldquofighters. Both types of boat are now based at Faslane, which is becoming Britainrsquos only base for underwater vessels.A vanguard-class Trident submarineBack in April, when he announced events to commemorate  years of CASD, the then defence secretary, Gavin Williamson, told the House of Commons: ldquoHalf a century ago, HMS Resolution glided into the Clyde and sailed into the history books.ldquoThat was the start of our longest sustained military operation ndash Operation Relentless ndash and the beginning of our continuous at-sea deterrent.ldquoSince then, there has always been a Royal Navy ballistic missile submarine at sea protecting our nation, and thousands of submariners have followed in the wake of Resolutionrsquos crew conducting vital work, unseen and undetected, every minute of every day.ldquoWe already honour our submariners with a deterrent patrol pin ndash often known as the bomber pin ndash giving recognition to their enormous efforts, but we want to go further still. Consequently, we are going to ensure that those who complete  patrols will now be recognised with the new silver bomber pin.ldquoFuture bomber pins will be made from metal taken from HMS Resolution, linking todayrsquos submariners with their forefathers and emphasising the longevity and the signicance of the -year mission.Respect for submariners does not mean the opponents of CASD will be celebrating ndash or even appreciating Mr Williamsonrsquos gesture. Scottish CND said celebrations were ldquohorrying. The carcass of Resolution ndash the first Polaris boat ndash remains in dock on the Forth. No nuclear submarine has been successfully dismantled since the were first launched. The bill to store them has toppedpound million since .A trident missile is launchedNow the four Trident boats ndash Vanguard class ndash are to be replaced too, with no plan in place for their safe disposal. The existing fleet is getting older and the next generation of "bombers" - Dreadnought classes - are still a long way from delivery.:What next for Britainrsquos undersea bombers That worries Professor Malcolm Chalmers, the deputy director of the Royal United Services Institite. Keeping a deterrent active at all times, he stressed, is far from easy and far from guaranteed.Prof Chalmers said: "This is a remarkable operational achievement only made possible by the dedication and sacrice of tens of thousands of people - both onshore and at sea - who have kept the fleet going."The criterion of keeping a boat on patrol at all times is a challenging one, and is made steadily more so as the submarines get older. Further delays in bringing the new Dreadnought submarines into service, therefore, could bring the Royal Navys ability to deploy continuously into question."Faslane, which dates to the Second World War, expanded into an old breakerrsquos yard on the Gare Loch, to house Polaris after the US system was bought from America in the s. The UK had separately developed its own A-bomb a decade before ndash but these were designed to be dropped from planes.Protests against Polaris missiles in Mark Ruskell, Scottish Green MSP and anti-nuclear activist, stressed that Clyde base had become a focal point for protest, galvanising Scots to oppose such weapons and even the political union which brought them north of the Border.He said: ldquoFaslane is a constant reminder that we are only minutes away from mutually assured destruction. Itrsquos become a brutal symbol and gathering point for the green and peace movements over the decades, but there is always a fresh sense of disbelief whenever I visit ndash just how can these vast, immoral weapons still play any strategic security role today ldquoIn a world increasingly ided by climate change and information wars, the risks from nuclear weapons have only intensied in recent years as nuclear states like the UK drive forward modernisation programmes. ldquoIrsquoll never stop campaigning against nukes, itrsquos part of the green movementrsquos DNA .:What next for Britainrsquos undersea bombers The Faslane base, HMNB ClydeLabour MSP Jackie Baillie - whose Dumbarton constituency includes Helensburgh and the Gare Loch - stressed how touch it was to serve underwater.She said:ldquoIn the th anniversary of the nuclear deterrent being based at Faslane, I want to pay tribute to all those who have served in the navy and in particular our submariners."The le of a submariner is not easy, separated from family for months on end living in the most cramped conditions imaginable. They do a tremendous job keeping us safe.ldquoThe civilian staff at Faslane are mostly local people and they have contributed to the success of Faslane and Coulport over the years too.ldquoHMNB Clyde occupies is biggest single site employer in Scotland and this matters hugely to our local economy.

title: mother-knew-glasgow-opens-linda-mccartney-show
story: A major retrospective of the photographic art of Linda McCartney, collected and curated by her family, has gone on display in Glasgowrsquos Kevingrove Art Gallery and Museum."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Linda McCartney retrospective at Kelvingrove","description": "Linda McCartney retrospective at Kelvingrove","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs sDfrMHfo-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests sDfrMHfo.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Video by Colin MearnsIt is the first time the exhibition of images - from showbusiness shots to intimate portraits of her husband, Sir Paul McCartney and children - has been shown in the UK.:Sir Paul McCartney on his late we Lindas photography ahead of Glasgow exhibitionThe show, called The Linda McCartney Retrospective, runs at the itself beloved museum until January.Sir Paul and his daughters Mary and Stella put together the show., a retrospective that includes one of her diaries from the s, displayed for the first time.The exhibition has previously been shown in Vienna, Seoul and Montpellier.Born in Scarsdale, New York, Linda McCartney studied art history at the University of Arizona.Her break came while working as an editorial assistant at Town and Country magazine.She used an unwanted invitation to a Rolling Stones promo party on the Hudson River to take pictures of the band and following the success of the images, she became a professional photographer.As the resident photographer at Fillmore East in New York, she took pictures of many of the greats: Otis Reading, BB King, The Doors, The Grateful Dead, Frank Zappa, The Who and Jimi Hendrix among others.In , Linda was voted US Female Photographer of the Year and soon afterwards became the first woman to have her work featured on the cover of Rolling Stone magazine with a portrait of Eric Clapton.Following her marriage, her work focused on the natural world, family le and social commentary.She continued to work prolically as a photographer until her death from breast cancer in . Her work has been exhibited by institutions including the International Center of Photography in New York, the Victoria  Albert Museum and the National Portrait Gallery in London.Themes in the show include The Sixties, Family Le, Self Portraits, Animals and Nature, People and Places, Making the Magic and Scotland, featuring pictures taken at the family home in Argyll and of people from local communities in Campbeltown, shape this signicant retrospective.She died from breast cancer in  at the age of .Sir Paul said: ldquoThe whole family loves to honour Lindarsquos work - she would have loved this because Glasgow was a place she loved.ldquoShe loved Scotland because it gave us a lot of fond memories, a lot of freedom and a lot of happy times.ldquoIt is nice to have all of that encapsulated in the Kelvingrove exhibition.Speaking to The Herald Magazine last week, Sir Paul, , reminisced about their time spent at High Park Farm near Campbeltown and what Scotland means to him and his family.:Yesterday director Danny Boyle on why we still love The BeatlesLooking through the photographs last week with The Herald, he said the family had been happy at their home in Scotland.ldquoVery much so, he said ldquoIt is funny because the first time I really heard anyone talk about it with a lot of fondness was John Lennon.ldquoHe had relatives up in Scotland who he liked a lot and he visited them when he was a kid. He would talk with great fondness of the crofts and the holidays hersquod had up in Scotland. So, there was always a nice feeling about it for me.ldquoThen, when I ended up getting the farm at Mull of Kintyre and going up there and spending some time, it had the same kind of resonance for me. Again, it was this fondness for the people and for the land. It constituted a form of freedom for us.ldquoWe could get away from all the things we normally did and just enjoy a lot of space. One thing about the farm was you could walk out at night and see  degrees of sky which you canrsquot do in a city.Sir Paul purchased High Park Farm in . The farmhouse, atop a hill overlooking Machrihanish Bay, came with  acres.He married Linda three years later.Stella McCartney, a celebrated fashion designer, said: ldquoThrough these images you meet the real mother I knew.ldquoYou see her raw and deep talent and passion for her art, photography.ldquoAhead of her time on every level, this mother-of-four still held her camera close like a companion, she captures the world around her through her eyes and this can be seen on the walls around the exhibition.ldquoHer humour, her love of family and nature and her moments framed with a slight surreal edge ... Scotland was one of her favourite places on Earth and so many images were taken there.The retrospective also includes one of Linda McCartneyrsquos diaries from the s and a selection of her cameras and photographic equipment.ldquoThere is the one of me on the fence with two of my kids, Sir Paul said.ldquoI think it captures the free spirit that we enjoyed when we came to Scotland. We escaped a lot of business stuff that was going on in London.ldquoThat picture shows the joy of being in the freedom of Scotland. The baby is Mary and the one hanging over the fence is my eldest daughter Heather.

title: farming-student-moves-beauty-beasts
story: Mum-of-two Katie Dubarry, , will graduate with a first-class honours degree in Agriculture at SRUCrsquos summer graduation ceremony at the University of Glasgowrsquos Bute Hall.She is one of a record  graduands achieving a first-class honours degree this year in subjects ranging from Agriculture, Rural Business Management and Environmental Resource Management, to Applied Animal Science, Horticulture, and Garden and Greenspace Design.Katie, who is originally from Lichfield in Staffordshire but now lives in Edinburgh, worked as a beauty therapist in France but became disillusioned with the job when she moved back to the UK.ldquoI wanted to learn about how we can live more sustainably, how we produce the things we do and how we consume things, said Katie. ldquoAll of these thought processes combined into an interest in farming and the ways people work the land, but I didnrsquot know the first thing about it.Five years after starting on the National Certicate course at SRUCrsquos Oatridge campus, Katie is graduating with a BSc degree from the Edinburgh campus, and ndash after taking a year out to represent SRUC as Vice President of the Student Association ndash is interested in continuing to PhD level.ldquoAfter the first year I was hooked, she said. ldquoAs I have worked through, I have discovered all about other aspects I had no idea were part of agriculture.Students from SRUCrsquos campuses in Edinburgh, Aberdeen, Dumfries, Fe, West Lothian and Ayr will receive awards for qualications ranging from PhD and postgraduate diploma to degree and HNC level.In his address to graduands Wayne Powell, Principal and Chief Executive of SRUC, said: ldquoI firmly believe that SRUC people are dferent. They have guts and a commitment that inspires them to make a dference, to drive forward their respective industries and make an impact.

title: tourism-boost-fife-pilgrim-way-re-opens
story: And now hardy hikers can retrace the steps of pilgrims across the centuries on a new walking route which criss-crosses its way through some of the countryrsquos most beautul countryside.The -mile Fe Pilgrim Way re-opens to the public today after extensive development and upgrading during the last five years at a cost of almost half a million pounds.The first new long-distance trail to open in the Kingdom since the Fe Coastal Path in , it follows a route from the Firth of Forth to St Andrews Cathedral and has been mapped out as closely as possible to mirror the path taken in medieval times.The Pilgrim Way passes through Pittencrief ParkPilgrimages to holy sites have been conducted since the Dark Ages and often involved seeking penitence for sins or redemption in the eyes of the Lord.But they were also an early form of tourism, and linked communities with visitors from other towns and lands they may not have encountered before.:Fringe chief warns against lsquoanti-tourismrsquo as Festival unveils showsThe Crusades to the Holy Land were launched, in part, to ensure the route was kept open for European pilgrims, and many routes ndash such as the Camino de Santiago in Spain and France ndash remain popular today. The new Scottish route can begin at Culross or North Queensferry, crossing through the heart of Fe taking in a host of Scottish treasures including medieval landmarks, picturesque villages and inland views of the Perthshire, the Forth and Tay estuaries and the Lomond Hills.Culross was where St Serf, a Roman missionary, established a religious community in the th century. Legend has it that he provided a home to Thenew, a princess of the Britons, when she was disowned by her family after falling pregnant out of wedlock.The child she bore would grow up to become St Kentigern ndash affectionately known as Mungo by St Serf ndash who established his own community in the land which would one day become Glasgow and remains the cityrsquos patron saint.His mother is remembered as St Enoch.Dunfermline Abbey is one of the sightsFrom this start, the path is peppered with historical and religious sites.Along the way it visits Dunfermline Abbey, the centre of Christian le in the area for more than , years, and the proud St Drostanrsquos Tower in Markinch, parts of which date to the th century and would have been a welcome site to walkers heading west.Overall, there are more than  sites of interest along the trail, including stone circles, battlefields, country mansions and examples of Fersquos long industrial heritage.The Way moves resolutely inland after a few miles on the coast, and has been knitted together from new and existing paths and through agreements with local landowners and communities to form an unbroken chain crossing the Kingdom.Walkers are guided by hundreds of posts marked with the Fe Pilgrim Way sign, and wayposts giving the number of miles to go to the next stage.:How Skye figures twice on Airbnbs top  Scottish destinations listIt is estimated to take six daysrsquo moderate walking, but hikers are also encouraged to try sections at a time.A new website, a walking map, a Pilgrims Passport ndash which lets walkers tick off the stages they have completedndash rest points and a smartphone app have also all been made available to help modern-day pilgrims on their way.It is hoped that, as well as attracting local walking groups, it will open up a previously unseen part of Scotland to visitors from the UK and overseas.Lord Thurso, VisitScotland chairman, said: ldquoScotland is renowned as a tourism destination with excellent walking trails and long-distance routes.ldquoThis is reflected by over .m domestic visitor trips to Scotland featuring walking. The new Fe Pilgrim Way offers a new route on Scotlandrsquos walking map, giving visitors the opportunity to explore dferent parts of the Fe on foot by delving into its past from medieval pilgrimage to modern industrial heritage while enjoying the great outdoors and the beautul scenery which Fe has to offer.ldquoScotlandrsquos reputation as a quality destination relies on continued investment and innovation in order to ensure that current provision meets future demand.Wayposts point the wayThe Fe Pilgrim Way received pound, funding from The National Lottery Heritage Fund Scotland towards the routersquos restoration, in addition to contributions from other organisations.:The Caledonian Camino: Plans for Scots coast-to-coast pilgrimage route mirroring famous Spanish trek#As part of the wider Fe Pilgrim Way project, a free, travelling exhibition will be launched today at Dunfermline Abbey named The Pilgrim Express.Stephen Carter OBE, chairman of Fe Coast and Countryside Trust Board, said: ldquoI would like to thank all involved in the completion of this new long distance route for Fe, which underlines the position of Fe as lsquoThe Outdoor Kingdomrsquo for the benefit and enjoyment of the citizens of Fe, and many thousands of visitors who choose to spend their leisure time in Fe.

title: jeremy-hunt-says-wants-turn-scotland-39-green-silicon-valley-39-harnessing-industries-future
story: The underdog in the race to succeed Theresa May as Prime Minister also hints today thathe won the Conservative leadership contest, he would slash duty on one of Scotlandrsquos prime exports: scotch whisky.As he and Boris Johnson prepare for this evenings one and only party hustings in Scotland, the Foreign Secretary uses an article in the Times to declare his devotion to the United Kingdom and have a swipe at his opponent ndash who saidhe became PM, he would add the words ldquoMinister for the Union to the title.He says: "My commitment to the Union is second to none but I donrsquot want to be a prime minister, who declares myself lsquoMinister of the Unionrsquo and thinks thatrsquos enough."I have a vision to restore Scotlandrsquos economy to its historic strength by looking to the industries of the future. The entire country can become a green Silicon Valley and an exporting powerhouse that leads the UK, not the other way around.Mr Hunt points out that, historically, Scotland has excelled at promoting ideas and inventions globally.ldquoWhere there is an existing market advantage - in Fintech, BioTech, or the food and drink industry - I will seek to drive that home, he declares.ldquoThat means a review of spirit duty to establish the best path to economic growth and the most tax revenue. Scottish whisky has an in-built, natural and nostalgic advantage over its competitors but we cannot get complacent there are markets that must be seized in South America and Asia.ldquoIf we deliver a good Brexit deal and follow it with the right trade deals, we can continue the Scottish whisky boom," adds Mr Hunt.As well as the Scottish hustings in Perth tonight, the ballot papers also go out today. As it is widely believed that most of the , or so Tory members will vote quickly, this in all practicality means the contest could be over this weekend with more than two weeks still to go before ballots close on July .Yesterday, Mr Hunt changed tack after he initially said he would allow a Commons vote on fox-hunting in which he would back its restitution in England and Wales.Later, however, he stressed: "But it wouldnt be my priority as Prime Minister. Were going to have Brexit, weve the social care system...weve got huge economic priorities that are going to have to be addressed so that wouldnt be where Id focus my energies."During a campaign visit in Yorkshire, Mr Johnson side-stepped the fox-hunting issue, saying his priority was to ldquoget Brexit done on October , to do everything I can to unite our countryhellipand then get our party ready to defeat Jeremy Corbyn."On social care south of the border, Mr Hunt set out a four-point plan, which would be explained in detail in a Green Paper to be published in his first  days in office. This would include a -year funding plan aligned with the -year plan he negotiated for the NHS, including additional state funding for local councils from the pound billion of fiscal headroom available.On the stump in Yorkshire, Mr Johnson said he too would immediately start work on social care reforms and set out two key principles, which were ldquono-one should face eviction from their home to pay for the cost of their care and everybodys got to have dignity and security in old age.Last night, at hustings in the county, the former London Mayor said he too would put the Union before Brexit but argued no Scottish voter would be able to support a UK government that did not push through Brexit after being asked to in the  referendum. Mr Johnson, therefore, insisted Brexit had to happen to save the Union.

title: herald-diary-snappy-chat-cia
story: SO the picture sharing site Instagram was not working for a few hours yesterday which got people who like to take obsessive numbers of pictures of themselves a bit upset. We liked the reaction of Americas Central Intelligence Agency no less, which went on that other social media site Twitter to declare: "Yes, we are affected by Instagram being down too. No, we didnrsquot cause it. No, we canrsquot fix yours. Did you try turning it off and back on again "Yolks on himOUR tales of workplace meals reminded retired cop David Russel: "A prankster colleague at the old Craigmillar Police Station in Edinburgh removed an egg intended as part of a night sht fry-up from another cops container. He then hard-boiled it and replaced it. causing much hilarity when the victim tried to break it into the frying pan."The following sht, stled laughter preceded the poor unfortunates lea- up to cracking that nights egg, causing him to blurt out: Youve done it againhavent you  before throwing it at the wall only to watch all that liquid running down the sides of the mess room."CrawlerAH the holiday tales are beginning to drt in. A reader on holiday in Torremolinos in Spain heard a Scottish youth in a bar say to a young woman: "I bet I can talk you into taking off your t-shirt." The young woman sneeringly dismissed his wager as extremely unlikely. At that the young lad added: "Ive just seen a spider crawl inside it."CuttingGROWING old, continued. Says Mary Duncan: "My bowling club friend Margaret was absolutely delighted to get her bus pass. First time using it, not knowing youre supposed to state your destination, she proudly put it on the scanner and waited expectantly. Driver: Where are you going  Margaret: Im going to the hairdressers. Driver: Yes, but where are you going  Margaret: Well, Im going to meet my Mum and then Im going to get my hair cut and... The driver was trying to be heard above the laughter of the other passengers as he once again asked where she was going."PricelessWE asked for your wedding stories and Phyllis Strachan in Milton of Campsie recalls: ldquoThe wonderful Rev James Currie whilst minister of Pollok Church many years ago told of the conversation he had with a groom soon to be married, who asked the minister how much he charged to marry him. The Rev Currie replied jocularly, lsquoHow much do you think your future we is worth rsquo When the groom gave his answer the Rev Currie replied, lsquoOk, but ahrsquoll gie ye chinge backrsquo.Bottoms upTHE new Brexit MEPs staged a strange revolution by turning their backs on the European Parliaments opening session. As James OBrien remarks: "I would like to apologise for my criticism of Brexit Party MEPs yesterday. By turning their backs on proceedings in Strasbourg they were simply putting the backsides they talk out of in front of their microphones."SweetMEANWHILE in the Tory leadership election, Boris Johnson has hinted at cutting the tax on sugar as it is unfair on poorer folk ndash so tax cuts for the rich, and more sugar for the poor. Sounds fair. As one reader tells us: "Is cutting the sugar tax the modern equivalent of Let them eat cake "

title: pause-dundee-women-must-always-guard-reproductive-rights
story: The practice was in a deprived London borough where women were living in poverty, having large families without the support of the fathers, drug use was common and so were the instances of children being received into care.ldquoSo he used to just stick them on the way out. By ldquostick them, he meant the contraceptive injection. A quick stick, without their knowledge.ldquoHa ha, my conversational companion said. Ha ... what Surreptitious sterilisation. What was the doctorrsquos justication  Mothers were struggling to cope or they were unable to prioritise the needs of their children due to outside factors. More babies would be a burden too great to bear ndash for the woman and for the health and social care systems.:Scheme offering Dundee mums supportthey take birth control is ethically dubious, experts warnDoing this without permission was, in the most favourable light you can cast, paternalistic. An abuse of power and negligence in another light. Itrsquos depressing how often Irsquove mentioned that anecdote to people and received the response, ldquoFair enough. They shouldnrsquot be having babiesthey canrsquot pay for them care for them.Already running successfully in England and Northern Ireland, the project offers intensive support to women who have had multiple children ndash on average three to four and in one case  ndash removed from their care, offering intensive practical, therapeutic and behavioural support.Such support, though, comes with one condition: the women agree to use long acting contraceptivessuch as the implant, injection or coil. A woman who becomes pregnant will be ldquophased out of the programme.Medical interventions such as these, of course, come with possible physical side effects, but the specialists behind the scheme insist a ldquopause from pregnancy is necessary for the women to, as chief social worker Jane Martin put it, ldquouse their time on the programme to effectively tackle destructive patterns, develop new skills and avoid further trauma.It is a bereavement but not widely recognised as such, particularly with the additional trauma of blame, guilt and sense of failure or injustice that can accompany the loss of the child.When a child is at home, often services are tailored to support and find the best outcome for the child or young person with lesser emphasis on the mother. With the Pause Programme, by removing the child from the equation, the focus becomes purely on the woman and what is best for her.This is almost, in itself, controversial, given how much store society sets on the ability of women to be an effective mother, and how ndash rightly ndash child-centric Scottish policy has become, with additional childcare hours, the Scottish Child Payment, the baby box, and the First Ministerrsquos commitment to care-experienced young people.But when the most intensive and high quality support comes with a serious caveat, is that really a choice and is it an ethical choice to offer  Particularly to women from a social strata where bodily and reproductive autonomy is in question in a way that it would never be for the middle classes. Think the two-child cap for Child Tax Credit and Universal Credit.Particularly when the cash savings of the Pause Programme are not easily overlooked: a briefing from Dundee Council suggested thatthe scheme meant the prevention of between six and ten pregnancies that would avoid between pound, and pound. million over five years.The scheme works on a hypothetical. That being hard to reach, women living chaotic lives will not be able to turn their lives around without the removal of additional babies from the equation.It also works on the hypothetical that this pregnancy pause is best for any future children but is that not then saying it would be better not to be born than to be born and be care-experienced Womenrsquos reproductive rights are perpetually under siege. Women in Northern Ireland still do not have access to abortion on an equal footing with their peers in the rest of the UK while abortion is a topic of routine political scrutiny and debate. When women are happily pregnant, society polices what they might eat, drink and participate in by using judgement as a form of control.In America we see Gilead levels of state control over womenrsquos bodies. The recent arrest and then, on Wednesday this week, dropping of charges against Marshae Jones, in Alabama, shows the importance of vigilance. Ms Jones was shot in the stomach but was arrested for manslaughter for initiating a fight, knowing she was pregnant.It may seem a stretch from the appalling strictures of the Yellowhammer State, but any policy that conflicts with womenrsquos reproductive rights must come under close scrutiny. In the case of the Pause Programme, there is a contradiction, in that, by focusing solely on a womanrsquos needs as a person and not as a mother, the programme also removes her autonomy in choosing pregnancy or not.ldquoThere have been trials already in parts of England, Stewart Hunter, convener for Dundee City Councilrsquos children and families services, said, ldquoAnd the feedback from women there has been fairly positive so thatrsquos comforting.We do not live in a political climate where ldquofairly positive is ethically sound enough to justy pausing a womanrsquos right to choose.

title: letters-unionists-blame-rise-snp
story: At Westminster, Conservatives have a dismal  MPs out of , with the SNP having , nearly three times that number. To make up for their shortfall, the Tories bray ceaselessly at the SNP from a sedentary position, to the extent that the Speaker had, on one occasion, to remonstrate with them about their bad behaviour, reminding them that the SNP was the third-largest party in the Commons, and deserving of more respect.At Prime Ministers Questions, Theresa May misses no opportunity to denigrate the SNP with remarks like ldquoScotland is doing better under this Government than it could ever do with that lot over there ndash and others express similar sentiments.How, precisely, do they reconcile such attitudes with encouraging Scots to transfer their votes to Unionist parties  Meantime, all the evidence points to a Unionist disaster at the next election ndash and the responsibility for that rests in their own hands. Without their historic failures, we would not have had an SNP government in Scotland in the first place,Douglas R Mayer, Currie.YOUR Letters Pages are certainly ied and informative with many contradicting views. Todaywe have Owen Kelly talking about a ldquopugnacious and reckless form of English nationalism, Alan Fitzpatrick talks about the SNP obsession with separation from the UK, Larry Cheyne has ldquoConservatives obsession with breaking up the EU, Ruth Marr ldquoScotlandrsquos decision to remain within the EU has been positively ignored, Allan Thompson ldquo a desperate rant by a First Minister, Robert Bell highlights the Brexit Party ldquoturning its back on Beethoven. For lighter relief R Russell Smith responds to Thelma Edwards with ldquonot to get new dungarees dirty ndash which brought to mind an exhortation from my parents ldquonot to get my new shoes scuffed when going out to play football.Returning to Alan Fitzpatrickrsquos point about the need for a Citizenrsquos Assembly in Scotland, I think I probably agree that it not necessary because our politicians in Holyrood elected by proportional representation are doing a fairly good job of knowing and representing the wishes of voters, and sensible Scottish voters are ing the incumbent party of government time after time. On the other hand, a Citizenrsquos Assembly is badly needed in England, given the current meltdown at Westminster, which Boris Johnson says is Englandrsquos parliament.I think Allan Thompson should spend more time on reading the detail. The  SNP MPs at Westminster have put forward not far off  proposals and amendments, many to the benefit of the UK and not a single one has been adopted. Indeed, some have been resurrected by other parties under the guise of a new proposal. Nicola Sturgeon has put forward a number of positive suggestions only to have them rejected by Theresa May or a Westminster government that simply does not want to know what the Scottish people want ndash Scottish assets, now thatrsquos a dferent matter.Alan M Morris, Blanefield.THE drip feed of anti-UK propaganda from the SNP continues day in day out, as Nicola Sturgeon and her SNP leadership colleagues claim it is ldquotoo late to save the Union and that Scotland is now on an ldquoinexorable journey towards independence Sturgeon predicts independence will be PM Mayrsquos lasting legacy", The Herald, July . The suggestion that devolution can be further strengthened after Brexit is simply dismissed by nationalists who have only ever considered devolution as a stepping stone to their overriding ambition to break-up the UK.Of course we have heard many times before from the SNP that another independence referendum is ldquoinevitable and the First Minister has explained that independence ldquotranscends all , so presumably justying the SNP Governmentrsquos many demonstrable failures through giving insufficient priority to the things that really matter in the lives of the people of Scotland such as education, health and the economy.Keith Howell, West Linton.Ms Sturgeon has not got a good record of predictions at all, and an ill-thought-out scheme to simply capitalise on current government problems in the vain hope that independence will solve them will simply be more of the same. Independence must be earned, not gained by default. The crystal ball is still full of the fog from Brexit.Dr Gerald Edwards, Glasgow G.ARE events pointing to a situation which our current political masters dont want us to know Theresa May says she wants a review of devolution. According to your sister paper The National, David Liddington refuses an FOI request to release a Government-instructed IPSOS Mori poll on attitudes to Scottish independence. Unionist politicians and their acolytes are desperate to persuade people to boycott the Peoples Assembly. Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt are suddenly full of compliments for Scotlands part in the Union. People are jumping to defend the monarchy as a cohesive force in the UK. The BBC and print media are giving any Unionist politician a really easy ride in any interview.Are there echoes of McCrone  Do they not want us to know that there is currently a momentum towards Scottish independence  The question we all have to ask is: are we willing to be duped again David Stubley, Prestwick.CAN you imagine being admitted to hospital to have a malignant tumour excised from a part of your anatomy where the sun never shines yet the surgeon says ldquoWe will deal with the cancer just before Christmas, meanwhile you have a plook on your bum we will squeeze that first  No  Neither can I. Yet with Brexitrsquos Sword of Damocles poised over the UK today in Westminster they debated protecting squirrels.Is this really how democracy is intended to   We have a road-show contest featuring two talentless millionaires, neither apparently with the ability to run a sweetie-shop, a decision being one that . per cent of the country cannot influence meanwhile in the face of a possible catastrophic period of austerity that could make the last decade look like the ldquoland of milk and honey our elected representatives discuss the pros and cons of dferent colours of tree-rats. Surely this is all a bad dream and tomorrow Irsquoll wake up back in the Shire with the rest of the Hobbits.David J Crawford, Glasgow G.

title: family-reunited-dog-six-year-search-thanks-microchip
story: Jodie Ferrier kept up a campaign to find her sprocker spaniel Fern from April , when she is believed to have been stolen from outside her home in Surrey, until Wednesday when she received a call from a vet to say they had found her.Is this the moment weve ALL waited for  ######Posted by Fern Found on Wednesday, July , ldquoI instantly fell to pieces, Mrs Ferrier, a -year-old personal assistant, told PA. ldquoI couldnrsquot quite believe what I was hearing.:Scotlandrsquos  best dog walksldquoWe ran through the confirmation of what the dog looked like and her name and everything like that and it all tallied, the information on the microchip was all correct and it was definitely my dog.Mrs Ferrier believes Fern, who was one when she disappeared, was stolen from their farm for breeding purposes.ldquoIt was absolutely heartbreaking, she said. ldquoWe were doing some work in the field ndash my husband, myself and our son. We had four dogs at that time, they were all out with us. The last time I saw Fern she was sat on the driveway and then two minutes later shersquod vanished.The family immediately launched a search of the area, bringing in neighbours, dog wardens and eventually the police.When none of that helped, Mrs Ferrier launched an online campaign, including a Find Fern Facebook page which over the years has developed a following of more than , people and threw up a number of potential sightings.: dog-friendly days out and destinations in ScotlandldquoWe actually went to meet a few dogs in person just to make sure because you canrsquot always tell from photographs and it was never her, she said. ldquoThe heartbreak, time and time again when the disappointment sets in and you realise that yoursquove got to start again ndash itrsquos just heartbreaking.But the search finally came to an end this week when Fern ldquowas stumbled across by a nice man who saw her wandering the street in Bracknell.He took her to a local vet, who scanned Fernrsquos microchip and called the family ndash who had since moved to the Isle of Wight.ldquoI slung my three children in the car and we drove to the ferry, Mrs Ferrier said.Staff at Twyford Veterinary Clinic stayed late so Mrs Ferrier and her three children ndash Ethan, Abbie and Rowan ndash did not have to wait until the morning to be reunited with their pet.ldquoThe moment that door opened I knew it was her instantly, said Mrs Ferrier. ldquoShe sort of went to walk past me then she doubled back and I donrsquot knowshe smelled something or recognised something ndash and then her tail started to wag and it just hasnrsquot stopped. Shersquos continued to wag that tail the whole time.Mrs Ferrier believes Fern has had at least two litters of puppies since they last saw her.She believes the dog may have been discarded by breeders once she was no longer useful to them, but aside from some itchy skin Fern appears to be in good shape.The reunion has been particularly emotional for eight-year-old Ethan, the only one of the familyrsquos three children who had been born when Fern was taken.ldquoHe was asking us all the time when his dog was coming home, Mrs Ferrier said. ldquoHe was two when she was stolen ndash hersquos eight years old now and hersquos never wavered in hoping that shersquod be back so we never stopped looking, never stopped trying.She said he was ldquostill in shock that Fern was back and ldquospent most of the day curled up with her.Mrs Ferrier said the story emphasised the importance of getting pet dogs microchipped, of keeping your details updated on the system and of vets scanning animals with which they come into contact.ldquoItrsquos such a massive point, she said. ldquoThese chips need to be implanted.ldquoAs long as you do those three things ndash chip, update and scan ndash it works.CREDIT - @findfernwithme

title: government-stick-manifesto-promise-tv-licence-fee-finds-poll
story: The BBC has announced the end of the universal benefit, saying it cannot afford to take on the financial burden from the Government.:Three months after its launch, how strong is the pulse of the nations newest TV channel Age UK carried out research with younger as well as older TV viewers on the issue after the broadcaster said the free licence would be restricted to those on pension credit."We should be ashamed of ourselves for even contemplating taking away their complimentary licence."Join Ricky Tomlinson  , others # Support our #SwitchedOff campaign aiming to save free TV licences for over s. Sign the petition here: https:t.co aDFsPxSr #TVLicence pic ZQofvaFmdash Age UKJune , The charity stated that % of those surveyed ndash aged  and over ndash said the Conservative Party should keep its manesto promise to fund free licences until .Age UK charity director Caroline Abrahams said the research,published as the BBC has been criticised for handing some of its stars pay rises, reflected ldquosolid support for maintaining free TV licences for our over-s.She added: ldquoWhat jumps out is how strong and consistent public opinion is on this issue, right across Great Britain ndash among men and women of all ages, all political persuasions, all levels of income, and in every region and country.ldquoSome pundits say that election manestos are no more than lsquowish listsrsquo, but the public clearly disagrees.She said the issue ldquoraises questions of fairness towards older people, as well as undermining public trust in politicians.:The SNP escalate complaint against BBC over misleading election graphldquoOur research shows that the next Prime Minister will find himself on the wrong side of public opinion unless he agrees to abide by the manesto commitment his party made to keep funding TV licences for the over-s.ldquoThere is still time for Jeremy Hunt and Boris Johnson to say that they will keep the promise their Party made to the public.Age UKrsquos online petition has now reached almost , and the charity says it has been ldquoflooded with calls and emails from people across the country who are worried about losing their free TV licence.It said the cost of the entitlement accounts for less than .% of public spending.The BBC has been criticised for giving pay rises, revealed in its annual report, to some of its stars.While some big names have taken cuts, Dan Walker, Justin Webb, Nick Robinson, JasonMohammad, Jo Whiley and Lauren Laverne are among those who have pocketed increases.The research was conducted via an internet omnibus survey by Kantar for Age UK. A sample of , GB adults aged  plus were interviewed from June  to .A Government spokesman said: ldquoWersquore very disappointed with this decision ndash wersquove been clear that we want and expect the BBC to continue this concession.ldquoPeople across the country value television as a way to stay connected, and we want the BBC to look at further ways to support older people.ldquoTaxpayers want to see the BBC using its substantial licence fee income in an appropriate way to ensure it delivers for UK audiences, which includes showing restraint on salaries for senior staff.

title: honorary-chairman-john-keane-saved-celtic-administration-retires
story: Hailed as one of the men who saved Celtic from the brink, John pledgedpound million to save Celtic from going into administration which kept the club afloat.The Director also backed Fergus McCannrsquos takeover with further crucial investment as well as giving backing to current members of the board and the majority shareholder Dermot Desmond.John played a hugely signicant role in preserving the Clubrsquos history and the club as a whole andserved as a non-executive director of Celtic Football and Athletic Club for well over  years.:The saving of Celtic:  years on. Part III: Fergus McCannHis crucial role was recognised at Celticrsquos AGM in , when he was confirmed as the Honorary Chairman of CFAC.Paying tribute to his role in maintaining the history of the club Celtic Chairman Ian Bankier said: ldquoWhen the Clubrsquos very survival was in doubt, John was there to play a crucial role and he is someone who should forever be regarded as one of the most important figures in the Clubrsquos history.ldquoI know with John standing down from the Board, our supporters will take this opportunity to applaud the fantastic contribution of a great Celtic man and join me in wishing him well on his retirement.ldquoI know, too, that John will continue to support the Club as passionately as he always did. John will always be a friend of the Club and we sincerely thank him for all he has done for Celtic.Dermot Desmond commented:ldquoJohn has been a lelong, passionate and steadfast supporter of our great Club. He has been a tremendous friend and support to me personally but above all he is a man who put the Club ahead of anything . As Celtic supporters, we all owe John an enormous debt of gratitude for everything he has done for the Club, in protecting our continuity, in preserving our history and ultimately in bringing Celtic to where it stands today.ldquoWe all wish John, Kathleen and the whole family all the very best for the future.:Hampden Park: An open letter by former Celtic owner Fergus McCannJohn Keane added: It has been an honour and privilege to be part of Celtic, a Club I have loved so dearly all my le. I would like to thank Dermot Desmond, Ian Bankier and Peter Lawwell and all other directors, past and present, who have worked together and so tirelessly in the best interests of the Club.ldquoI also wish to pay tribute to all other staff at the Club and, of course, our supporters who give so much to Celtic and make it the wonderful institution it is today. I will always be a Celtic supporter and I wish the Club nothing but continued success for the future.

title: atmosphere-banter-lacking-maybots-codebase-coda
story: So her handkerchief-free goodbye was in Codebase, a hub for IT start-ups in Stirling.And only the Maybot, who lacks the code for irony, could make a speech on saving the Union a short hop from William Wallacersquos most famous victory.On US Independence Day.The Codebase coda had all the hallmarks of a May event. No atmosphere  Check. Zero banter  Uh-huh. Everyone got better things to do  Too right.:Theresa May tells her successor: Dont trust Nicola SturgeonActually, thatrsquos not entirely fair. There was a small crowd outside ndash protesters waving Yes Saltires on poles. One sported a T-shirt with the anatomically taxing instruction ldquoshove the union up your a***.There were no takers.Local students had also taped a poster to the building, in a deceptive Tory blue, asking ldquoShould Scotland be an independent country It was quickly removed, presumably by someone whose answer is a hard No.Across the road, a banner hung from a lamppost showing a gory red map of ldquoBloody Scotland, an advert for a coming crime writing festival.Or possibly Boris Johnsonrsquos next election slogan.Inside, the criminal theme continued. The audience of a few dozen party activists had been joined by former Labour MSP Gordon Jackson QC, now Dean of the Faculty of Advocates. ldquoIrsquom nosy, explained the surprise guest.Yoursquod have to be. :Theresa May brushes aside Nicola Sturgeons assertion that Scottish independence will be her legacy as Prime MinisterMrs Mayrsquos outriders had touted a moving, even ldquoinspirational speech. The iron caress of her vocal cords meant that was never likely.However it did carry a sting.She had come to lecture her successor on the importance of holding the UK together.She was a champion of the Union. An expert. In fact, on her watch, it had never been weaker, thanks to Brexit and that Nicola Sturgeon not playing ball on devolution, and nothing teaches you how to fix stuff like breaking it, you know.So her advice to Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt was not to trust tricksy Nats who only wanted independenceand fight for the Union before itrsquos ldquotoo late.It was a curious swan song.Enthusiastic about the Unionrsquos qualities, fretful about its longevity. At the end, in a former council building where elections were often decided on a cut of the cards, you wonderedthe UKrsquos chances were now also -.

title: snp-lodge-official-complaint-ofcom-jeremy-vine-show
story: Panellists were discussingBoris Johnsons campaign to become Prime Minister amidreports thathe didbecomeprime minister support for independence could surge.Paul Burrell, Princess Dianarsquos former butler, who appeared on the Channel  show saidthe report on a surge in Scottish independenceBoris became PM wasldquofood forNicola Sturgeon.This really has to be seen to be believed.I mean for goodness sakes...Scotland, by itself  How is it going to survive The Jeremy Vine show on Channel , th June .Part  : pic BYXOSbSCv:Twitter storm after lists on Jeremy Vine show claims Scotland could never survive aloneHe then made a comment about how Scotland could not survive going it alone stating:ldquoI mean, for goodness sake, Scotland, by itself  Howrsquos it going survive  It has hellipwhat does it have ...oil, and a monster in a lake,and...whisky.It is now understood that Ofcom has been contacted by the party afterChannel  ignored and failed to reply to emails from the party raising concerns.In their complaint, the SNP say the broadcast was in breach of sections . and . Ofcomrsquos broadcasting code, citing the lack of impartiality and Vinersquos insistence in continuing the discussion despite a lack of a pro-independence voice.Explaining the SNPrsquos decision to lodge an official complaint, Hannah Bardell MP, the SNPrsquos media spokesperson atWestminster, told our sister paper The National: ldquoThis was one of the most inaccurate discussions about Scotland and independence ever broadcast on network television.ldquoThatrsquos saying something given the level of nonsense Scottish audiences witnessed in the run-up to .ldquoWersquoll continue to work with journalists, editors and, where necessary as in this case, broadcasting regulators to make sure Scotlandrsquos voice is heard ndash they are duty bound to ensure their programmes have due accuracy and due impartiality, not serve up guff like this.:If this doesnt make you want Scottish independence, nothing will Readers hit out at Jeremy Vine showldquoUltimately the broadcasters are only harming themselves with embarrassing low-level output like this from Channel  ndash which will only make Scottish audiences switch over.A spokesperson for Channel  said: ldquoWe regularly cover questions around Scottish independence on our daily current affairs programme, reflecting a broad range of opinions and voices.ldquoThe comments expressed by the contributors in the programme reflect their personal viewpoints, not those of the channel.The comments made on the June  episodewere lambasted by viewers with some stating that the narrow-minded comments were an advert for Scottish independence.

title: glasgow-built-supercomputer-satellites-blast-orbit
story: A pair of supercomputer satellites belonging to US data and aerospace firm Spire Global were built by its team based in Glasgow, with the aim of optimising and speeding up its ability to send information back to scientists on Earth.:Vacant shops turned into art studios and exhibition spaces in new Glasgow strategyThe Scottish city is one of six locations where the company operates, with other sites in San Francisco, Washington DC, Boulder, Singapore and Luxembourg.Lt-off of the Soyuz-.b launch vehicle from Vostochny #Soyuz #Gklaunch pic NcPefjlUmdash GK Launch ServicesJuly , Satellites are essential to everything from navigation to weather monitoring, but data can be slow to download due to the amount of traffic, meaning more are needed to help companies process and cherry-pick data before sending it back.The two new nanosatellites hitched a ride on Russian space agency Roscosmosrsquos Soyuz-.b rocket, launching at .am Moscow timefrom its Vostochny Cosmodrome spaceport.ldquoOver the past five years, Glasgow has become the best place in Europe to build these innovative, small satellites, with Spire Global alone manufacturing more than  on the Clyde, said Graham Turnock, chief executive of the UK Space Agency.:In pictures: Business HQ goes to spaceThe two satellites were among  to ride-share into orbit, with satellites from Germany, France, USA, Israel, Sweden, Finland, Thailand, Ecuador, Czech Republic and Estonia attached, alongside three of Russiarsquos own satellites, which include a new weather satellite called Meteor-M No.-.A previous attempt to launch the weather satellite with a payload of  micro-satellites in November  failed to reach orbit due to an apparent programming error.# ########: ###### ########## ##### ######-######## laquo####-.#raquo # ########## ##########  ####.# #MeteorM: launch photos from #Vostochny cosmodrome pic zClNxOWmdash #########July , ldquoWe see these parallel supercomputing scalable devices as a crucially important next step for a new level of accuracy and timeliness in space data analytics, said Peter Platzer, chief executive of Spire Global.ldquoThe UK Space Agency and European Space Agencyhave been extremely forward-looking and supportive of Spirersquos innovative approach to deploying space technology to solve problems here on Earth.Khalil Kably, pioneer programme manager for ESA, added: ldquoThe whole idea of the Pioneer Programme is to give European and Canadian industries access to space, rapidly and at low cost.ldquoAs soon as they have an innovative idea, such as supercomputing by Spire here, we want people to be able to try it in orbit.ldquoItrsquos the ability to go from a new idea to market very quickly, through in-orbit validation.An avionics technology demonstration satellite called DoT- made by Guildford-based Surrey Satellites was also included in the launch.
